awd_titl_txt: Stellar Atmospheres in the Laboratory: A Testbed for Fundamental Atomic Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Most stars---including our Sun---will end their lives as white dwarf stars, which no longer undergo nuclear fusion.  Understanding white dwarf stars is an important tool for astronomy because these stars can serve as cosmic clocks that probe the age and history of the universe.  This research project will create in the laboratory conditions that are similar to those found on the surfaces of white dwarf stars.  A detailed analysis of the light absorbed and emitted by atoms under such conditions will allow astronomers to better understand white dwarf stars.  This project will train graduate students in sophisticated laboratory techniques, and it will support science outreach to local high schools.

The research team will conduct new laboratory measurements that will provide key benchmarks for atomic line broadening observed in white dwarf stars.  They will make these measurements using an experiment that they have built for the Z-machine at Sandia National Laboratories.  The experiment is capable of producing hydrogen, helium, and carbon plasmas that are similar to those in white dwarf  photospheres.  Accurate atomic spectral line parameters measured in these laboratory plasmas would allow astronomers to accurately diagnose plasma conditions at the surfaces of white dwarf stars and test theories of line broadening there.  White dwarf stars could then be used to constrain the age and history of the Galactic disk, Galactic halo, and individual stellar clusters, and as astrophysical laboratories in which to study the fundamental physics of crystallization, phase separation, diffusion, and plasmon neutrino emission.  This project will train graduate students in the methods and applications of laboratory astrophysics, and it will provide opportunities to undergraduate students from the Freshman Research Initiative program at UT Austin.

por.por_cntn:
White dwarf (WD) stars are dense, compact remnants of more than 97% of all stars, including stars like our sun. Due to their small size, high mass, and relative physical simplicity, WDs have tremendous scientific potential for astronomy and physics. They could be the most accurate, independent chronometers for constraining the age and formation history of the galactic disk, the galactic halo, individual stellar clusters, and the universe. WDs also provide us with the opportunity to study physics in extreme environments, e.g., plasmon neutrino emission and crystallization at very high temperatures and densities. However, to draw accurate conclusions about such processes, we need accurate surface temperatures and gravities. The most precise method for determining these properties compares the shapes and depths of white dwarf spectral lines to theoretical models.  However, the extreme plasma conditions of white dwarf atmospheres have made these models difficult to test in the lab, leaving the astronomical results uncertain.  Thus, only laboratory benchmarks will unlock the full astronomical potential of these stars. With the resulting improved methods and parameters, the study of galaxy formation will no longer be constrained to observations of faint, high-redshift galaxies, but will also be possible by looking in our own backyard, the Milky Way.

We have developed an experimental platform, using the world's most powerful x-ray source, the Z machine at Sandia National Laboratories, that allows us to measure several critical aspects of the line broadening theory used to determine the fundamental parameters of white dwarf stars. This allows us to measure hydrogen, helium, and carbon plasmas at the conditions characteristic of the atmospheres of WDs. This work would not be possible without access to the Z facility and the technical support of staff at SNL.

For hydrogen, our low-density results agree with previous measurements and calculations for the spectral line H-beta. At higher densities, we find agreement between the lines H-beta and H-gamma when measured in emission, but when measured in absorption they disagree in expected widths by 20-30%. Interestingly, we see this same sort of disagreement between individual absorption lines observed in WD stars. This is an unexpected result and we are currently scrutinizing our experiment to make sure that this is not due to an artifact of our platform.

For our helium measurements, we initially believed that they were inconsistent with theoretical predictions of neutral helium broadening. We have since improved our analysis techniques and find that our new derived widths are consistent with theory; we published this result in 2022. 

We have also fielded more shots with thinner entrance windows, which allows more x-ray flux from the Z pinch into our gas cell. This allows us to repeatably achieve the higher temperatures necessary to study the conditions relevant to the surfaces of hot carbon atmosphere white dwarf stars.

In addition to our experimental work, we have continued to advance our theoretical efforts to improve line broadening theory. Our graduate students have continued to improve the numerics and the physics of our state-of-the-art line profile code Xenomorph, which was written by a previous graduate student in our group. We have published the first description of the method and results of this code and are preparing a publication that will include a grid of H line profiles. These calculations will be made freely available to the scientific community for inclusion in codes used to produce models of white dwarf spectra. 

At UT-Austin, we run an astronomy course for the Freshman Research Initiative program that involves freshmen and sophomores directly in cutting-edge research. The diversity of the experimental and modeling efforts enables undergraduate students to take possession of a subset of our data and directly experience the addictive excitement of discovery and learning. This is a powerful motivating experience designed to help launch the careers of the next generation of scientists. 

Finally, making "star stuff" in the laboratory lends us a powerful voice in the media and with our colleagues. For instance, our work was featured in two "Seeker" videos that were released in 2020:

  • Inside the Most Powerful X-Ray Source in the World (> 175,000 views, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eFhotBY0nQM)
  • The Z Machine Recreates a Dying Star on Earth (> 390,000 views, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G9tj7wHbePo)
